description.narrative:
Cooperativa de Terras Comunitarias da inicitativa para Terras Comunitarias (CTC-COOP/iTC) har ansökt om ett stöd för perioden 2015-2017 och Sverige avser att bidra med SEK 25,5 miljoner (kärnstöd). Målet med insatsen är att individer och grupper ska göra socialt och miljömässigt hållbara investeringar på landsbygden och i förortsamhällen. Baserat på den nationella kontextanalysen har CTC-COOP/iTC lyft fram följande behov: i) förbättra uppföljning av hur lagstiftningen för markrättigheter implementeras så att lokalbefolkningen erhåller den lagstadgade ersättning i form av utvecklingsprojekt. ii) Stärka relevansen för lokalbefolkningens konsultationsprocesser i förhållande till privata investeringar. iii) Koppla processen med markavgränsningar till den lokala utvecklingsprocessen. iv) Ge stöd till lokalbefolkningens planer för samhällsutveckling så att de leder till konkreta projekt som ger resultat på lokalnivå.
CTC-COOP/iTC avser att uppnå målet genom att framförallt förbättra implementeringen av den nationella lagstiftningen för markrättigheter. CTC-COOP/iTC koordinerar insatsen i nära samarbete med relevanta nationella myndigheter och ministerier, och en stor del av arbetet i fält implementeras av kontrakterade så kallade ’Service Providers’. Insatsen är efterfrågestyrd, implementeras i områden baserat på lokalbefolkningens behov och där de grundläggande förutsättningarna för att genomföra insatsen är uppfyllda.
Sverige har bidragit med stöd till CTC-COOP/iTC under 2006-2014 som har varit i linje med den planerade insatsen och de uppnådde resultaten anses vara goda. En extern utvärdering lyfte särskilt fram resultaten på lokalnivå, så som förbättra grundförutsättningar för lokal organisering och förbättrad egenmakt. Det framtida programmet ska expandera geografiskt och avsikten är att på sikt implementera insatsen i landets alla provinser.
CTC-COOP/iTC är sedan slutet av 2014 registrerat som ett icke vinstgivande kooperativ, från att tidigare ha varit administrerat av KPMG. Sverige och övriga givare har gett sitt stöd till skapandet av en oberoende organisation men det innebär en viss administrativ risk, eftersom alla administrativa kontroller och rutiner behöver etableras på nytt. Bedömningen är att CTC-COOP/iTC har kapaciteten att införa de nödvändiga rutinerna och avsikten är att tidigare erfarenheter från KPMG kommer att överföras. Genom skapandet av en oberoende organisation så kommer ägarskapet stärkas ytterligare.
Insatsens planerade totala budget för tre år är cirka SEK 150 miljoner. Övriga givare är Nederländerna, Schweiz, Storbritannien (ingår avtal under 2015) och Danmark (ingår avtal under 2015). CTC-COOP/iTC har fortlöpande dialog med andra möjliga givare för att öka givarbasen.

Cooperativa de Terras Comunitarias da inicitativa para Terras Comunitarias (CTC-COOP/iTC) has applied for a support during 2015-2017 and the Embassy of Sweden (EoS) intends to contribute with SEK 25,5 million (core support). The main goal of the contribution is to encourage individuals and groups to make socially and environmentally sustainable investments in rural and suburban communities.
The national context analysis for the intervention has highlighted following needs: i) Better monitor the implementation of the legislation so that the land use rights of the local communities result in fair sharing of local communities in development projects; ii) Enhance the relevance for the local populations’ consultation processes in relation to private investments. iii) Link the land delimitation process with the local development process; iv) Transform the community development agendas into concrete projects with an impact at the community level.
CTC-COOP/iTC aims to achieve its objectives by improving the implementation of the national legislation for land rights. CTC-COOP/iTC coordinates the intervention in close relation with relevant national institutions and ministries, and a large part of the work in the field is implemented by contracted service providers. The intervention is demand-driven, implemented in areas based on the local communities’ needs and where the basic conditions for the fulfilment of the intervention can be met. EoS has provided supported CTC-COOP/iTC during 2006-2014 that has been in line with the planned intervention and the achieved results are assessed as satisfying. An external evaluation highlighted the positive results on local level, as preparation of communities and empowerment. The planned intervention will expand geographically and the aim is to implement the intervention in Mozambique’s all provinces.
CTC-COOP/iTC is since the end of 2014 registered as a non-profit cooperative, previously it was administrated by KPMG. EoS and other donors gave their support to development of an independent organization but it implies a certain administrative risk, since all administrative controls and routines need to be established once again. The assessment is that CTC-COOP/iTC has the capacity to establish the necessary procedures and the intention is that previous experience from KPMG will be transferred. Through the creation of an independent organization the ownership will be further strengthened. The planned budget for the entire intervention is SEK 150 million. Other donors are the Netherlands, Switzerland, UK (enter into agreement during 2015) and Denmark (enter into agreement during 2015). CTC-COOP/iTC has a continuous dialogue with other possible donors to increase the number of donors.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Based on the intervention’s theory of change there is a need that the contribution obtains several outcomes to reach the overall objective. The intervention’s planned results achieved by the implemented activities all feed into the outcomes as stated in the theory of change. However, the change that need to achieved is also dependent on the jointly support from other actors within the field of land rights (national authorities, private sector and other stakeholders). It is assessed that the intervention’s planned results for 2017 have been obtained. The most significant result for 2017 is the number of local Natural Resources Management Committees - CGRN - that have received compensation by the government for the exploration of natural forests on their land. CTC-COOP/iTC has (together with other partners/interventions) invested considerable time and effort to create CGRNs during the past few years, since it has been seen as an important mechanism for possible integrated rural development and it is the established channel by the government for financial compensation related to natural resources exploration (mainly natural forest). Once a community has had its land right title registered a local CGRNs can be created after fulfilling a number of set criteria. The possible funds received by CGRNs should be invested in agreed community projects. During previous years the result of creating a CGRN have had limited impact, since there had been insufficient progress on the governmental side to monitor and collect the fees related to natural based exploration by private companies, and therefore a large number of established CGRNs did not receive its entitled income. In 2017 the ministry of Land, Environment and Rural Development – MITADER – after a few years of restructuring manages to increase the state revenue related to private exploration of natural forest and this was partly passed on to the CGRNs in accordance with the land right law (20 % of revenue). It was initially planned that 20 CGRNs established and supported by the intervention could receive governmental funds, but by the end of the year the total number of CGRNs that received funds were 107. If this positive trend continuous it could be seen as a bit of a breakthrough since it is a result of joints efforts and interaction between communities, authorities and private sector. It will also give an incentive for the rural population to obtain its land right titles, preserve natural forests and organize around a common objective, which will bring rural development funds to its community. This achievement would not have been obtained without the implementation of the land rights law.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
